{{short description|Multiple of the unit byte, equivalent to 1,000 petabytes}} {{About|the unit of information|the company that manufactured data backup products|Exabyte (company)}} {{Quantities of bytes}} The '''exabyte''' is a multiple of the unit [[byte]] for [[Computer data storage|digital information]]. In the [[International System of Units]] (SI), the [[SI prefix|prefix]] ''[[exa-|exa]]'' indicates multiplication by the sixth power of 1000 (10<sup>18</sup>). Therefore, one exabyte is one [[quintillion]] [[byte]]s ([[Long and short scales|short scale]]). The unit symbol for the exabyte is '''EB'''.
: 1 EB = {{gaps|10<sup>18</sup>|bytes}} = {{gaps|1000<sup>6</sup>|bytes}} = {{gaps|1|000|000|000|000|000|000|B}} = 1000 [[petabyte]]s = {{gaps|1|[[1,000,000|million]]|[[terabytes]]}} = {{gaps|1|[[1,000,000,000|billion]]|[[gigabyte]]s}}. : 1000 EB = 1 [[zettabyte]] (ZB)
A related unit, the [[exbibyte]], using a [[binary prefix]], is equal to {{gaps|1024<sup>6</sup>| |}} (={{gaps|2<sup>60</sup>)|bytes}}, about 15% larger.
==Usage examples and size comparisons== * A processor with a [[64-bit computing|64-bit]] address bus can [[address space|address]] 16 [[exbibyte]]s of memory,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/zosbasics/com.ibm.zos.zconcepts/zconcepts_102.htm|title=A brief history of virtual storage and 64-bit addressability|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[IBM]]|accessdate=17 February 2007}}</ref> which is over 18 exabytes. * The world's technological capacity to store information grew from 2.6 ("optimally compressed") exabytes in 1986 to 15.8 in 1993, over 54.5 in 2000, and to 295 (optimally compressed) exabytes in 2007. This is equivalent to less than one [[Compact disc|CD]] (650 MB) per person in 1986 (539 MB per person), roughly four in 1993, 12 in 2000, and almost 61 in 2007. Piling up the imagined 404 billion CDs from 2007 would create a stack from the [[Earth]] to the [[Moon]] and a quarter of this distance beyond (with 1.2 mm thickness per CD).<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Hilbert|first=Martin|last2=López|first2=Priscila|date=April 2011|title=The World’s Technological Capacity to Store, Communicate, and Compute Information|url=http://www.martinhilbert.net/WorldInfoCapacity.html/|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|volume=332|issue=6025|pages=60–65|doi=10.1126/science.1200970|pmid=21310967}} See also: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iIKPjOuwqHo video animation]</ref> * The world's technological capacity to receive information through one-way [[broadcast]] networks was 432 exabytes of information in 1986, 715 exabytes in 1993, 1,200 exabytes in 2000, and 1,900 in 2007 (and with all the preceding examples assuming that those figures represent "optimally [[Data compression|compressed]]" data).<ref name=":0" /> * The world's effective capacity to exchange information through two-way [[telecommunication]] networks was 0.281 exabytes of information in 1986, 0.471 in 1993, 2.2 in 2000, and 65 exabytes in 2007 (yet again, all such amounts listed are strictly working off the basis that the data was in an "optimally compressed" form).<ref name=":0" /> * In 2004, the global monthly [[Internet traffic]] passed 1 exabyte for the first time. In January 2007, Bret Swanson of the [[Discovery Institute]] coined the term ''exaflood'' for a supposedly impending flood of exabytes that would cause the Internet's [[congestive collapse]].<ref name="DISC">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB116925820512582318|title=The Coming Exaflood|author=Swanson|first=Bret|date=20 January 2007|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=17 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/139885/article.html|title=Internet Could Max Out in 2 Years, Study Says|author=Gross|first=Grant|date=24 November 2007|website=[[PC World]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071126041511/http://www.pcworld.com/article/id,139885-pg,1/article.html|archivedate=26 November 2007|url-status=live|accessdate=28 November 2007}}</ref> Nevertheless, the global Internet traffic has continued its [[exponential growth]], undisturbed, and {{as of|2010|03|lc=y}}, it was estimated at 21 exabytes per month.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2361820,00.asp|title=Cisco: Internet Moves 21 Exabytes per Month|last=Miller|first=Michael J.|date=25 March 2010|website=[[PCMag]]}}</ref> * The global data volume at the end of 2009 had reached 800 exabytes.{{Citation needed|date=December 2018}} * According to an [[International Data Corporation]] paper sponsored by [[Dell EMC|EMC Corporation (now Dell EMC)]], 161 exabytes of data were created in 2006, "3 million times the amount of information contained in all the books ever written", with the number expected to hit 988 exabytes in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emc.com/digital_universe/|title=An Updated Forecast of Worldwide Information Growth Through 2011|author=Gantz|first=John|date=March 2008|publisher=[[International Data Corporation|IDC]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428084830/http://www.emc.com/digital_universe|archive-date=2009-04-28|url-status=dead|accessdate=2009-04-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.cjr.org/feature/overload_1.php|title=Overload! Journalism’s battle for relevance in an age of too much information|author=Nordenson|first=Bree|date=1 April 2009|magazine=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|accessdate=20 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/31/AR2009033103318.html|title=Turn Off, Tune Out, Drop In|author=Parker|first=Kathleen|date=December 2008|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=11 April 2009}}</ref> * A gram of [[DNA]] can theoretically hold 455 exabytes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22530084-300-glassed-in-dna-makes-the-ultimate-time-capsule/|title=Glassed-in DNA makes the ultimate time capsule|last=Aron|first=Jacob|date=11 February 2015|work=[[New Scientist]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161015103726/https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22530084-300-glassed-in-dna-makes-the-ultimate-time-capsule/|archive-date=15 October 2016|url-status=live|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref> * In 2014, [[DARPA]]'s [[ARGUS-IS]] [[surveillance system]] could stream 1 exabyte of [[high-definition video]] per day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.csoonline.com/article/2223941/microsoft-subnet/darpa-s-unblinking--all-seeing-1-8-gigapixel-camera-stare-on-pbs-rise-of-the-drones.html|title=DARPA’s unblinking, all-seeing 1.8-gigapixel camera stare on PBS Rise of the Drones|last1=Pseudonym: Ms. Smith|first=|date=29 Jan 2013|work=CSO Online|access-date=|publisher=IDG}}</ref> * According to the [[CSIRO]], in the next decade, [[astronomer]]s expect to be processing 10 [[petabytes]] of data every hour from the [[Square Kilometre Array]] (SKA) telescope.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csiro.au/news/ps3ng.html|title=From Molecules to the Milky Way: Dealing with the Data Deluge|date=7 November 2007|publisher=[[CSIRO]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926233027/http://www.csiro.au/news/ps3ng.html|archive-date=2011-09-26|url-status=dead|accessdate=10 November 2007}}</ref> The array is thus expected to generate approximately one exabyte every four days of operation. According to [[IBM]], the new SKA telescope initiative will generate over an exabyte of data every day. IBM is designing hardware to process this information.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.computerworld.com.au/article/319128/ska_telescope_provide_billion_pcs_worth_processing_updated_/|title=SKA telescope to provide a billion PCs' worth of processing (updated)|last1=Tim|first1=Lohman|date=18 September 2009|website=[[Computerworld]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906111600/https://www.computerworld.com.au/article/319128/ska_telescope_provide_billion_pcs_worth_processing_updated_/|archive-date=6 September 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> * According to the Digital Britain Report, 494 exabytes of data was transferred across the globe on June 15, 2009.<ref name="Digital Britain Report">{{Cite web|url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/images/publications/digitalbritain-finalreport-jun09.pdf|title=Digital Britain Final Report|last=Carter|first=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Carter, Baron Carter of Barnes|date=June 2009|publisher=[[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]]; [[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]]|page=3|via=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]]|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090630141322/http://www.culture.gov.uk/images/publications/digitalbritain-finalreport-jun09.pdf|archive-date=2009-06-30|url-status=dead}}</ref> * Several filesystems use disk formats that support theoretical volume sizes of several exabytes, including [[Btrfs]], [[XFS]], [[ZFS]], [[exFAT]], [[NTFS]], [[HFS Plus]], and [[ReFS]]. * The [[ext4]] file system format supports volumes up to 1.1529215 exabytes in size, although the [[userspace]] tools cannot yet administer such [[filesystem]]s. * [[Oracle Corporation]] claimed the first exabyte tape library with the SL8500 and the T10000C [[tape drive]] in January 2011.<ref name="Press release">{{cite web|url=http://www.oracle.com/us/corporate/press/302409|title=Oracle Introduces StorageTek T10000C Tape Drive|last=|first=|date=31 January 2011|website=|publisher=[[Oracle Corporation]]|access-date=}}</ref> * 100 years of uncompressed video at [[8K UHD]] (7680×4320 pixels), 120 frames per second and 16-bit per color channel ([[RGB]]) would amount to 72 exabytes.{{fact|date=January 2020}}
===All words ever spoken=== Allegedly, "all words ever spoken by human beings" could be stored in approximately 5 exabytes of data.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/12/opinion/editorial-observer-trying-measure-amount-information-that-humans-create.html|title=Trying to Measure the Amount of Information That Humans Create|author=Klinkenborg|first=Verlyn|date=12 November 2003|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=19 July 2006}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://searchstorage.techtarget.com/sDefinition/0,,sid5_gci944596,00.html|title=How many bytes for...|last=Rouse|first=Margaret|date=|website=|publisher=techtarget.com|accessdate=2006-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.uns.purdue.edu/html3month/2005/051206.McKay.petabyte.html|title='Robbie the Robot' making data easier to mine|last=Christiansen|first=Amy Page|date=6 December 2005|website=|publisher=[[Purdue University]]|accessdate=17 February 2007}}</ref> This claim often cites a project at the [[UC Berkeley School of Information]] in support (although this project is now outdated and therefore not entirely accurate).<ref name="UCB">{{Cite journal|last=Lyman|first=Peter|last2=Varian|first2=Hal R.|last3=Charles|first3=Peter|last4=Good|first4=Nathan|last5=Jordan|first5=Laheem Lamar|last6=Pal|first6=Joyojeet|display-authors=2|date=30 October 2003|title=How Much Information 2003?|url=http://www2.sims.berkeley.edu/research/projects/how-much-info-2003/|journal=|publisher=[[University of California, Berkeley]]|volume=|page=2|pages=|accessdate=19 July 2006|via=}}</ref> The 2003 [[University of California, Berkeley]], report credits the estimate to the website of [[Caltech]] researcher Roy Williams, where the statement can be found as early as May 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ccsf.caltech.edu/~roy/dataquan/|title=Data Powers of Ten|author=Williams|first=Roy David|publisher=[[Caltech]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990508062723/http://www.ccsf.caltech.edu/~roy/dataquan/|archivedate=8 May 1999|url-status=dead|accessdate=19 July 2006}}</ref> This statement has been criticized.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000110.html|title=More on the 5 exabyte mistake|author=Liberman|first=Mark|authorlink=Mark Liberman|date=12 November 2003|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614194555/http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000110.html|archive-date=14 June 2018|url-status=live|accessdate=19 July 2006}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://brian.carnell.com/archives/years/2003/12/000022.html|title=How Much Storage Is Required to Store Every Word Ever Spoken by Human Beings?|author=Carnell|first=Brian|date=31 December 2003|website=Brian.Carnell.Com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206081135/http://brian.carnell.com/archives/years/2003/12/000022.html|archivedate=6 February 2006|url-status=dead|accessdate=19 July 2006}}</ref> [[Mark Liberman]] calculated the storage requirements for all human speech at 42 [[zettabyte]]s (42,000 exabytes, and 8,400 times the original estimate) if digitized as 16 kHz 16-bit audio, although he did freely confess that "maybe the authors [of the exabyte estimate] were thinking about text".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000087.html|title=Zettascale Linguistics|author=Liberman|first=Mark|authorlink=Mark Liberman|date=5 November 2003|website=|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]|accessdate=17 February 2007}}</ref>
Earlier studies from the University of California, Berkeley, estimated that by the end of 1999, the sum of human-produced information (including all audio, video recordings, and text/books) was about 12 exabytes of data.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mg0AAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA6&ots=3nx_JPfDAa&dq=Juan%20Enriquez%20(Fall%E2%80%93Winter%202003).%20%22The%20Data%20That%20Defines%20Us%22&pg=PA56#v=onepage&q=Juan%20Enriquez%20(Fall%E2%80%93Winter%202003).%20%22The%20Data%20That%20Defines%20Us%22&f=false|title=The Data That Defines Us|author=Enriquez|first=Juan|date=Fall–Winter 2003|website=|publisher=CIO Magazine|accessdate=19 July 2006}}</ref> The 2003 Berkeley report stated that in 2002 alone, "telephone calls worldwide on both [[landline]]s and mobile phones contained 17.3 exabytes of new information if stored in digital form" and that "it would take 9.25 exabytes of storage to hold all U.S. [telephone] calls each year".<ref name="UCB"/> [[International Data Corporation]] estimates that approximately 160 exabytes of digital information were created, captured, and replicated worldwide in 2006.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D8NMAG802.htm|title=So much data, relatively little space|author=Bergstein|first=Brian|authorlink=Brian Bergstein|date=5 March 2007|magazine=[[BusinessWeek]]|accessdate=5 March 2007}}</ref> Research from the [[University of Southern California]] estimates that the amount of data stored in the world by 2007 was 295 exabytes and the amount of information shared on two-way communications technology, such as cell phones, in 2007 as 65 exabytes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-12419672|title=Global data storage calculated at 295 exabytes|author=Stewart|first=Jon|date=11 February 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=|website=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://uscnews.usc.edu/science_technology/how_much_information_is_there_in_the_world.html|title=How Much Information Is There in the World?|author=Wu|first=Suzanne|date=10 February 2011|publisher=[[University of Southern California|USC]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402011603/http://uscnews.usc.edu/science_technology/how_much_information_is_there_in_the_world.html|archive-date=2 April 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>
===Library of Congress=== The content of the [[Library of Congress]] is commonly estimated to hold 10 terabytes of data in all printed material. Recent estimates of the size including audio, video, and digital materials start at 3 petabytes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.loc.gov/thesignal/2012/04/a-library-of-congress-worth-of-data-its-all-in-how-you-define-it/|title=A "Library of Congress" Worth of Data: It’s All In How You Define It|author=Johnston|first=Leslie|date=25 April 2012|website=|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|access-date=}}</ref> to 20 petabytes. Therefore, one exabyte could hold a hundred thousand times the printed material or 50 to 300 times all the content of the Library of Congress.
===Google=== In 2013, [[Randall Munroe]] compiled published assertions about [[Google]]'s data centers, and estimated that the company has about 10 exabytes stored on disk, and additionally approximately 5 exabytes on tape backup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://what-if.xkcd.com/63/|title=Google's Data Centers on Punched Cards|last=Munroe|first=Randall|authorlink=Randall Munroe|date=14 October 2013|website=[[xkcd]]|publisher=|accessdate=2014-05-10}}</ref> The company has not commented on Munroe's estimate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/randall_munroe_comics_that_ask_what_if|title=Randall Munroe: Comics that ask "what if?"|author=Munroe|first=Randall|authorlink=Randall Munroe|date=March 2014|website=|publisher=TED|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref>
